pr_title: SONARJAVA-3372 Rule S5803: Class members annotated with @VisibleForTesting should not be accessed from production code

timeline.message:
Add class check & refactoring

Fix ruling tests

Add class check & refactoring

Fix ruling tests

timeline.bodyText: There is a suspicious extra space at the end of the title. You might want to check on Jira.
timeline.author: m-g-sonar

replies.bodyText: In the ticket title in Jira there is a space at the end. Will fix on both sides
replies.author: margarita-nedzelska-sonarsource

timeline.bodyText: Why not be even more precise and add the folder which will contain directly the classes we are searching for?
timeline.author: m-g-sonar

timeline.bodyText: is suspicious here. Also, RSPEC mentions classes, while here we only have methods and fields. I guess you should re-generate the  metadada.
timeline.author: m-g-sonar
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@ +

@VisibleForTesting can be used to mark methods and fields whose visibility restrictions have been relaxed more than necessary for

timeline.bodyText:
missing g at the end :)
Also, I fee that it would be nice to mark the fully qualified names with <code> blocks
timeline.author: m-g-sonar
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@ +

@VisibleForTesting can be used to mark methods and fields whose visibility restrictions have been relaxed more than necessary for +the API to allow for easier unit testing.

+

Access to such methods and fields only possible thanks to this relaxed visibility is fine for test code, but it should be avoided in production +code.

+

Supported framework:

+

* Guava (com.google.common.annotations.VisibleForTestin)

timeline.author: m-g-sonar

timeline.bodyText: you can probably already return here if the symbol is unknown.
timeline.author: m-g-sonar

timeline.bodyText:
in fact, isFieldMethodOrClass() is probably simply !symbol.isUnknown() && !symbol.isPackageSymbol().
By construction, it will then only be a method, a variable or a type... As we don't have other kinds of symbol.
timeline.author: m-g-sonar

replies.bodyText:
@m-g-sonar for methods and classes it's easy, we can test them with symbol.isMethodSymbol() for symbol.isTypeSymbol().
But for fields, symbol.isVariableSymbol() is not enough. We want to exclude local variables, method parameters, and lambda parameters. I think the owner of a local variable is the method declaration. What is the best way to test if a symbol is a class field?
replies.author: alban-auzeill

timeline.bodyText: I think I would move this below, after we are sure it's a valid symbol to be considered
timeline.author: m-g-sonar

timeline.bodyText: This one looks like a FP to me (while a bit borderline), we are inside a class itself annotated with @VisibleForTesting, so it feels to me that it's OK to do call a something which is also annotated with VisibleForTesting. What's your opinion of it?
timeline.author: m-g-sonar

replies.bodyText: I think we should exclude those members, is the owner is annotated @VisibleForTesting too
replies.author: margarita-nedzelska-sonarsource

replies.bodyText: I thought about it and I think we should report this issue. The 'Logger', which is used inside 'Closer' and 'Closer' are in different files, so if 'Logger' is marked as private, it is not visible in 'Closer'
replies.author: margarita-nedzelska-sonarsource

@VisibleForTesting can be used to mark methods, fields and classes whose visibility restrictions have been relaxed more than necessary for the API +to allow for easier unit testing.

+

Access to such methods, fields and classes only possible thanks to this relaxed visibility is fine for test code, but it should be avoided in +production code.

+

Supported framework:

+

* Guava
